question: How come even though the US economy is doing as good as it's been since 2007 and we aren't at war our national debt continues to increase?
human_answer: The national debt level of the US measures how much money the federal government owes its creditors and is the level of federal debt held by the public. The national debt continues to rise because the US government almost always spends more than it takes in. As the US economy grows, the amount of revenue the government can use to pay its debts grows as well. Additionally, a larger economy generally means that the country's capital markets will grow and the government can tap them to issue more debt. As a result, the country's ability to pay off debt, and the effect that debt might have on the country's economy, is dependent on how large the debt is as a proportion of the overall economy, not the dollar amount.
webgpt_answer: The national debt of the United States continues to rise due to expenses exceeding revenue. Although the economy is strong, government revenue is usually less than its revenue owing to several factors. Since the government spends more than what it earns, it faces a budget deficit each year. The government has to borrow money in order to cover the deficit, which contributes to the national debt. The national debt has grown over the last decade due to the Great Recession and the fiscal policy response to it. Even before the recession, however, there was a structural mismatch between spending and revenues. That mismatch has expanded in recent years even as the economy has experienced a long period of sustained growth. The December 2017 enactment of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (TCJA) has also contributed to the national debt. The TCJA cut individual and corporate tax rates, which caused a substantial reduction in revenues. On the spending side, recent budget agreements have allowed for higher spending levels.
gpt3_answer: The national debt has been increasing for years, even when the US economy is doing well. This is due to a variety of factors, including the rising cost of entitlements such as Social Security and Medicare, government spending on programs like the military, infrastructure, and education, and the fact that the government has to borrow money to make up for the difference between what it collects in taxes and what it spends.   Additionally, tax cuts, such as the 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, can contribute to the national debt by reducing the amount of money the government takes in and increasing how much it has to borrow. When the US economy is doing well and unemployment is low, the government can take in more revenue, but it can still spend more than it takes in, leading to an increase in the national debt.   Finally, the US government is subject to economic cycles. During good economic times, the government can take in more revenue and reduce the national debt, but during times of recession, the government can lose revenue and have to borrow more money to make up for the difference. Thus, even when the US economy is doing well, the national debt can continue to increase.

question: Why is it that soap can wash almost anything off of your hands but doesn't wash its fragrance off of you?
human_answer: Soap is made from a combination of fat or oil heated with lye. When fragrances are added to soap, it is usually in the form of scented oil that combines with the oil and lye used to make the soap. A person's skin has a layer called the stratum corneum that contains natural lipids, which act as a fatty layer to contain the body's water. When oils are applied to the stratum corneum, they mix in with the lipids and sink into the layer, thus remaining on the skin instead of being washed off.
webgpt_answer: Soap acts as a surfactant and emulsifier, which makes it an excellent cleanser.  It can surround oil, making it easier to rinse it away with water.  Soap has the ability to act as an emulsifying agent, which means that it can suspend oil/dirt in such a way that it can be removed.  Soap’s molecules are polar, which allows them to bond with both water and oil.  Soap can bond to the oil molecules and then pull them away from a surface as it is carried off by water.  The soap molecules will pry oil molecules off of surfaces and suspend them within water, which can now wash them away.  In addition, soap decreases the surface tension of water, allowing water molecules to bond easier with a surface.  This allows water to clean more deeply.
gpt3_answer: Soap is a mild surfactant, meaning it has the ability to reduce the surface tension of water molecules and bind them to dirt and bacteria molecules. This is why soap is so effective at washing away dirt, oil and bacteria from your hands. However, the molecules that make up soap's fragrance are much larger than the dirt, oil and bacteria molecules, so they don't bind as easily to the water molecules. This is why soap's fragrance remains on your skin even after washing, whereas the dirt and bacteria are washed away. Additionally, the fragrance molecules may be adsorbed onto the skin, which means they stick to the skin and are not easily washed away. Some soaps contain ingredients like glycerin that help to keep the fragrance on your skin for longer. So, while soap is effective at removing dirt, oil and bacteria from your hands, it doesn't wash away its fragrance as easily.
alpaca_answer: It's true that soap can be used to clean almost anything off of your hands, however, it cannot be used to remove all of the fragrance from your body. Soap is an effective cleaning agent as it breaks down the chemical bonds of the substances it comes into contact with, allowing them to be rinsed away. However, fragrances are often made up of hundreds of different molecules, which are much more difficult for soap to break down and remove. This is why even though soap can be used to clean the hands, it does not remove all of the fragrance from your body.</s>
gpt3_wdoc_answer: Soap is an effective cleanser because of its ability to act as an emulsifier and surfactant, allowing it to suspend oils and grease and break them up into smaller particles, making them easier to rinse away with water. Soap also has an additional function; it can decrease the surface tension of water, allowing it to spread more easily and reach deeper into the dirt and grime. However, when soap is used on skin, it does not wash off the fragrance of the soap itself. This is because the molecules that make up the fragrance are too large for the soap to capture and suspend in the water. These molecules, along with the oils and dirt that soap is able to capture, are too heavy to be washed away and remain on the skin as the water runs off. The fragrance molecules also have different electric charges and are non-polar, meaning that they are not attracted to the soap molecules, and so the soap does not bond with them. As a result, the fragrance molecules remain on the skin even after the soap has been rinsed off.

Unfortunately, the fragrance molecules do not have the same properties as the soap molecules, so they are not as easily removed.</s>

question: what do you do if you get pulled over?
human_answer:
The first thing you should do is pull over to a safe spot in a safe manner. This means turning on your blinker to indicate any lane changes and slowly maneuvering to the side of the road as soon as possible. You should then discard anything that may give the officer negative preconceptions about you, like a cigarette, and roll down the window. 

The safest thing to do from there on out is to cooperate with the officer, since the officer does not know you and will likely operate under the assumption that you are dangerous (until you show otherwise). You can give small cues to indicate that you are paying attention to what the officer says, and of course you want to avoid interrupting them.

You also have the right to remain silent. The officer is also not legally allowed to search your car unless they have explicit permission. However, if the officer requests you to get out of the car, you are legally required to do so.
webgpt_answer: When you are pulled over by a police officer, your actions and words can have a huge effect on any legal proceedings that might follow. You should normally turn off your engine, roll down your window all the way, put out a cigarette if you have one and discard any chewing gum, place your hands on the steering wheel, and, if it's dark, turn on your interior light. These actions will tend to allay any fears the officer might have. Stay in the car until and unless the officer directs you to get out. Don't start rummaging through your back pocket for your wallet and license, or in your glove compartment for your registration, until the officer asks you for them. Be honest with the police and ask for an explanation if something is unclear. Finally, don't argue with the police officer. You can contest the citation in court after the fact if you wish.

Once the officer approaches your vehicle, roll down the window and keep your hands visible on the steering wheel. Listen to the officer and be respectful in your responses. Follow the officer's instructions and avoid making any sudden movements. Lastly, answer the officer's questions truthfully, and if you feel you need to, you can politely request to speak to your lawyer.

question: TIL that about 10 trillion of the 14 trillion dollar debt in the US is domestically owned. ELI5 how we owe ourselves 10 trillion dollars.
human_answer: The U.S. national debt is the total of the two federal debt categories - public debt and intragovernmental holdings like Social Security. Public debt is comprised of debt held by the U.S. banks and investors, the Federal Reserve, state and local governments, mutual funds, pension funds, insurance companies, and savings bonds.  This means U.S. citizens, via their retirement money, own most of our national debt.

Almost one-third of the federal debt is held by federal accounts while the remaining two-thirds is held by the public. As of September 2019, there was $22.7 trillion of outstanding federal securities. Of that, $5.9 trillion was money that the federal government owed itself. The intragovernmental holdings are mostly borrowed from the Social Security system, which was created to allow for future benefits. Another major holder was the Federal Reserve system.

question: Why will a file load to 99% with no problem then hang for what seems like forever?

webgpt_answer: One reason files load to 99% and then hang is that the file is copied into a buffer. When the file is completely in the buffer, it displays 99.9%, but it's still being written to the disk which is slow. If the buffer and the file are huge, then it stays at 99.9% for a long time. Another reason is that the progress bar we see is just a prediction, not accurate most of the time. It will be faster than it actually is. This means that the actual task might still be running at 79 percent or 89 percent, not even close to completion. Other reasons include antivirus software, file caching, out of memory, and computer performance.

question: What happens if I traveled back a few days in time, and somebody calls my cellphone?
human_answer:
Although many people are fascinated by the idea of changing the past or seeing the future before it's due, no person has ever demonstrated the kind of back-and-forth time travel seen in science fiction or proposed a method of sending a person through significant periods of time that wouldn't destroy them on the way. As physicist Stephen Hawking said, "The best evidence we have that time travel is not possible, and never will be, is that we have not been invaded by hordes of tourists from the future."

However, if the two devices have the same IMEI and SIM information, the network may not be able to tell them apart and the call will go through. In this case, the network would send a packet to the two receivers telling them they have a call. The two receivers would then respond to the packet. The cell tower would then receive two ACK messages. It is unclear what would happen next, but it is possible the tower would ignore the second ACK message, allowing the call to go through, or it could clue in to the fact that there is a phony phone and boot them both off the network until the situation can be figured out by a human employee.

question: ; How do ancient civilizations get covered by dirt, sand, etc?
human_answer: Some ancient civilizations become buried from natural disasters, such as the volcano eruption in Pompeii. Others are submerged underground from layers of events piling on top of them — dust blowing over from nearby areas, mudslides, earthquakes reshaping the land, etc. Rising ground levels may also be responsible for why certain civilizations have become buried. Archaeologists digging up civilizations may be a little biased when uncovering the remains of underground societies because most buildings and artifacts that remained on the surface would have been rummaged by humans passing by.
webgpt_answer: When ancient cities were abandoned, plant seeds quickly took root and created more bulk from the CO2 they pulled from the air. Their roots stabilized the soil created from rotting plant matter and the layers gradually built up. Erosion also played a role in covering ancient ruins. The ground level of ancient cities tended to rise: new buildings were built on top of the ruins of old ones because it was less labor intensive than removing the rubble. Also, rivers periodically flooded and added layers or silt, while wind constantly blew in sand and dust. As a result, the only ancient ruins we find are buried deep beneath the surface.

question: What causes us to imagine feeling ants/insects crawling on us after seeing one?
human_answer: This sensation is called formication. It is a type of paresthesia and tactile hallucination. It could also be a sign of several underlying conditions such as fibromyalgia, Parkinson's disease, drug and alcohol withdrawal, diabetic neuropathy, and diseases of the spinal cord and peripheral nerves.
webgpt_answer: The condition is called formication, which is a type of paresthesia. Formication is classified under a skin sensation experienced by a person due to various causes, such as tingling or prickling sensations, including the feeling of "pins and needles." The root word of formication is formica, which is a Latin word that means ant. Sometimes, formication could also be perceived as painful, burning, or tingling sensations. In reality, there’s no physical cause of the “crawling” sensation, but a few people believe that there are real insects under their skin – no matter how the doctors or experts reassure them that it’s only in their mind. Formication can also be caused by static electricity, which can cause the movement of body hair due to the skin’s particle being attracted to it, leading to the “crawling insects” sensation, or like bugs are crawling on the skin even though there is nothing there.
gpt3_answer: It's a phenomenon called "formication," which is defined as the sensation of crawling, tingling, or burning on the skin, similar to the feeling of ants or other insects crawling on it. It's experienced by many people, and can be caused by a wide range of factors. For example, some medical conditions, such as a low iron count, hypothyroidism, or skin conditions like eczema or psoriasis, can cause formication. Medications like antidepressants, antipsychotics, and corticosteroids can also cause it. Additionally, psychological factors like severe stress or anxiety can lead to formication.   In the case of seeing an ant or insect and then feeling like you have insects crawling on you, it's possible that the sight of the insect triggers a form of psychosomatic response, where your mind and body react to the sight of the insect as if it's actually crawling on you - even though it's not. This could be because of a fear of insects, or because of a general feeling of unease or distress.   Whatever the cause, formication is a very real and uncomfortable phenomenon, and it's important to talk to a doctor if you experience it. They can help you identify any possible medical causes and provide treatments to ease the sensation and help you manage it.
alpaca_answer: Imagining feeling ants/insects crawling on us is a cognitive illusion called the Occipital Cortex Illusion (OCI). OCI is caused by a misalignment between the physical location of an object in the visual field and its representation in the occipital cortex, the part of the brain responsible for visual processing. This misalignment triggers the illusion that the object is located elsewhere, often with the impression that it is crawling on the person’s skin.</s>

It is believed that this is caused by an individual seeing an insect or other creature and then imagining feeling the same sensation on their skin. This can be exacerbated by an individual’s feeling of anxiety or fear which can cause the sensation to seem more real. question: What is the difference between sigma bonds and pi bonds?
human_answer:
A sigma bond is a chemical bond formed by the linear or co-axial overlapping of the atomic orbitals of two atoms. A pi bond is a type of covalent bond that exists between atoms where the electrons are on top and bottom of the axis connecting the nuclei of the joined atoms. It is formed by the parallel or lateral overlapping of the atomic orbitals. The differences between sigma and pi bonds are that:

Sigma bonds are formed by head-to-head overlapping of orbitals, whereas pi bonds are formed by lateral overlapping.

Sigma bonds are stronger than pi bonds.

Sigma bonds can be formed between both s and p orbitals whereas pi bonds are mostly formed between p and d orbitals. 

The single covalent bonds between atoms are sigma bonds. When there are multiple bonds between atoms, pi bonds can be seen.

Pi bonds result in unsaturated molecules.

Sigma bonds allow free rotation of atoms whereas pi bonds restrict the free rotation.
webgpt_answer: Sigma bonds are the strongest kind of covalent bond, and pi bonds are the weakest. Sigma bonds are formed by head-on overlapping between atomic orbitals, and pi bonds are formed by the sidewise positive (same phase) overlap of atomic orbitals along a direction perpendicular to the internuclear axis. The axes of the atomic orbitals are parallel to each other during the formation of a pi bond, whereas the overlapping is perpendicular to the internuclear axis. Sigma bonds are generally stronger than pi bonds because the extent of the overlapping of atomic orbitals is greater during the formation of a sigma bond than during the formation of a pi bond. Additionally, a pi bond is formed only in addition to a sigma bond, and atoms prefer to form a strong sigma bond rather than a weak pi bond. Pi bonds are weaker than sigma bonds because the degree of overlap is lower.

In addition, sigma bonds are formed by the sharing of electrons between two atoms, while pi bonds are formed by the sharing of electron pairs. The main difference between sigma bonds and pi bonds is that sigma bonds are stronger and more directional, while pi bonds are weaker and less directional.

question: How does venture capital work?
human_answer:
Venture capital is a form a financing where private investors, who are usually quite well off, invest in start-ups. The investors, or "venture capitalists," provide funds to or help manage new groups that they believe will have exponential or long-term growth. 

Typically, investing in a start-up involves some degree of risk, but it can also yield high reward. There are even groups, like the Strategic Communications Group, to help venture capitalists make strategic decisions.
webgpt_answer:
Venture capital is money invested in a company's balance sheet and infrastructure with the goal of boosting the company's size and credibility so that it can be sold to a corporation or so that the institutional public-equity markets can step in and provide liquidity. In essence, the venture capitalist buys a stake in an entrepreneur's idea, nurtures it for a short period of time, and then exits with the help of an investment banker. 

In a typical start-up deal, for example, the venture capital fund will invest $3 million in exchange for a 40% preferred-equity ownership position. The preferred provisions offer downside protection. For instance, the venture capitalists receive a liquidation preference. A liquidation feature simulates debt by giving 100% preference over common shares held by management until the VC’s $3 million is returned. In addition, the deal often includes blocking rights or disproportional voting rights over key decisions, including the sale of the company or the timing of an IPO.
gpt3_answer: Venture capital is a type of financing used by startups and other high-growth businesses to help fund their operations and growth. It is typically provided by groups of investors, such as venture capital firms or angel investors, who are willing to invest their own money in exchange for a stake in the business.   The venture capital process begins when a business presents its plan to a venture capital firm. The firm will then review the plan and determine whether they believe it is a good investment opportunity. If they approve the plan, they will provide the business with a certain amount of money, usually in the form of equity or preferred stock. The firm will also typically provide advice and guidance to the business in order to ensure the success of the venture.  Venture capital investments are typically made in stages. At the initial stage, the venture capital firm will provide the business with a seed investment in order to help them get started. They may also provide additional funding at subsequent stages as the business grows and develops.  The venture capital firm will usually take a seat on the board of directors of the business in order to provide guidance and support. This allows them to have more involvement in the decision-making process and ensure that their investment is being used wisely.  The venture capital firm will also typically negotiate a return on their investment, usually in the form of a percentage of the company’s profits or an equity stake in the business. This allows them to benefit from the success of their investment, while still allowing the business to remain independent.  Venture capital is a great way for high-growth businesses to access funding and advice. It allows them to get the resources and guidance they need to take their business to the next level, while still maintaining control of their own destiny.
alpaca_answer: Venture capital works by providing funds to early-stage or start-up companies with the expectation of generating a financial return. Venture capitalists invest money in exchange for equity stakes in the companies they invest in. This means that the venture capitalists become shareholders in the company and have the potential to make a lot of money if the company is successful. Venture capitalists help companies access resources and expertise that may not be available to them otherwise, in exchange for a share of the company’s future potential success.</s>

 Furthermore, venture capitalists help startups hone their business plans, manage their operations, and access other resources to ensure the company's success. In return, the venture capitalists typically receive a seat on the startup's board of directors and a share of the company's profits. 
 
 Venture capital funds are raised either through public or private offerings, and are often limited partnerships that can include other investors such as corporations, governments, and other investment vehicles. The money from the venture capital fund may be used to fuel research and development, product expansion, acquisition of equipment, or working capital. 
 
 Ultimately, venture capital provides a much-needed resource for startups, allowing them to reach their full potential and rewarding investors with above-average returns.</s>

question: How does money go from my pocket, through the stock market, and to support the business I've bought stock from?
human_answer: The stock market works through a series of exchanges. When you buy stocks, you are buying shares of ownership in the company. By buying these shares, you help to raise money to fund the company and help it grow. Also, the sale of stocks creates and sustains wealth for investors.
webgpt_answer: Companies sell stock, or partial ownership in the company, to investors in order to raise money. Those companies increase or decrease in value, and as such, the value of your investment will rise and fall.  The stock market works through a network of exchanges, such as the New York Stock Exchange or the Nasdaq.  Companies list shares of their stock on an exchange through a process called an IPO, or initial public offering. Investors purchase those shares, which allows the company to raise money to grow its business. Investors can then buy and sell these stocks among themselves, and the exchange tracks the supply and demand of each listed stock. That supply and demand help determine the price for each security, or the levels at which stock market participants - investors and traders - are willing to buy or sell.  Buyers offer a “bid,” or the highest amount they’re willing to pay, which is usually lower than the amount sellers “ask” for in exchange. This difference is called the bid-ask spread. For a trade to occur, a buyer needs to increase his price or a seller needs to decrease hers.
gpt3_answer: When you buy stock in a business, your money goes to the stock market, which is essentially a marketplace for stocks and other securities. When you buy stock, the money is transferred from your account to the stock market, where it is held in escrow until the stock is sold. The stock market then works to match buyers and sellers, and the money from the sale is transferred to the company's financial institution. The company can then use the money from the sale of stock to fund various aspects of the business, such as paying for the cost of goods sold, investing in new products or services, and paying for operating expenses. Money may also be used to pay dividends to shareholders, which is a portion of the company's profits that are distributed to the shareholders. The company can also use the money to buy back its own stock, which can increase its value and benefit shareholders. Overall, when you buy stock in a company, your money passes through the stock market and ultimately ends up being used to support the business you've invested in.

This money is used to produce goods and services, hire new employees, pay dividends to shareholders, and buy back existing stock. Ultimately, the money you put into the stock market through buying stocks is recycled back into the economy, helping the businesses you've invested in to grow and thrive.</s>

question: How did the positions in basketball get their names?
human_answer: Historically, basketball players have been assigned to positions defined by the role they play on the court, from a strategic point of view. The three main positions are guard, forward, and center, with the standard team featuring two guards, two forwards, and a center. Over time, as more specialized roles developed, each of the guards and forwards came to be differentiated, and today each of the five positions are known by unique names, each of which has also been assigned a number: point guard (PG) or 1, the shooting guard (SG) or 2, the small forward (SF) or 3, the power forward (PF) or 4, and the center (C) or 5.
webgpt_answer: Basketball positions are named after the role they play on the court, from a strategic point of view. Historically, these players have been assigned to positions defined by the role they play on the court, from a strategic point of view. Broadly speaking, the three main positions are guard, forward, and center, with the standard team featuring two guards, two forwards, and a center. Each of the five positions are known by unique names, each of which has also been assigned a number: 1-point guard, 2-shooting guard, 3-small forward, 4-power forward, and 5-center. The point guard is the team's leader and typically the best passer and dribbler. The shooting guard is usually the team's best shooter. The small forward often has an aggressive approach to the basket when handling the ball. The power forward and the center make up the frontcourt, often acting as their team's primary rebounders or shot blockers, or receiving passes to take inside shots. The center is typically the larger of the two.
gpt3_answer: The positions in basketball have evolved over the years. The original five positions were known as guards, forwards, center, rover, and pivot. Guards were typically smaller and faster players who were responsible for bringing the ball up the court and initiating the offense. Forwards were typically bigger, stronger players who were responsible for rebounding and defending the hoop. Centers were typically even bigger and stronger players who were responsible for scoring and protecting the paint. Rovers were typically the most agile and versatile players who were responsible for filling any gaps between the other four players. Pivots were typically the tallest players who were responsible for protecting the basket and blocking shots.  In the 1950s, the rover and pivot positions were replaced by the forward-center and guard-forward positions. The forward-center was a combination of the forward and center positions and was responsible for scoring, rebounding, and defending the hoop. The guard-forward was a combination of the guard and forward positions and was responsible for bringing the ball up the court and initiating the offense, as well as rebounding and defending the hoop.   In the 1980s, the positions were further refined and the guard-forward position was split into the shooting guard and small forward positions. The shooting guard was typically smaller and faster, while the small forward was typically bigger and stronger. The shooting guard was responsible for scoring and defending the perimeter, while the small forward was responsible for rebounding and defending the hoop.   Today, the five positions in basketball are the point guard, shooting guard, small forward, power forward, and center. The point guard is typically the smallest and fastest player who is responsible for bringing the ball up the court and initiating the offense. The shooting guard is typically a slightly bigger and faster player who is responsible for scoring and defending the perimeter. The small forward is typically a stronger and more agile player who is responsible for rebounding and defending the hoop. The power forward is typically the strongest and most agile player who is responsible for scoring and defending the hoop. The center is typically the tallest and strongest player who is responsible for scoring, rebounding, and protecting the paint.
alpaca_answer:
The names of the positions in basketball are derived from the Latin words for their respective actions. For example, the name "point guard" is derived from the action of directing the offense, while the name "center" is derived from the position's role of setting up the offense and "centering" the court. The other positions are named similarly. 
 
 Additionally, some positions were named according to their location on the court. The "shooting guard" position, for example, is named because it is located near the basket and is responsible for shooting the ball. Other positions such as the "small forward" and "power forward" positions are named based on their size and physicality.</s>

question: Why oil and gas rigs may cause earthquake and falls?
human_answer:
Extracting oil and gas from shale rock involves cracking, or fracturing, a layer of underground rock with a high-pressure mix of water, sand, and chemicals, a process known as fracking. As the oil and gas are released, those injection fluids and briny water also come up. That wastewater is later disposed of in what are called injection wells, or sometimes disposal wells. It's the rapid injection of fluid during wastewater disposal, not the fracking process itself, which usually causes earthquakes. 

The number of earthquakes is increasing in regions where fracking is common. In fact, 20% of the earthquakes in the central United States may be attributed to just four of these wells. And injected fluids in high-volume wells triggered earthquakes over 30 km away.
webgpt_answer: When oil and gas are extracted from shale rock, it involves fracturing a layer of underground rock with a high-pressure mix of water, sand, and chemicals. As the oil and gas are released, those injection fluids and briny water also come up. That wastewater is later disposed of in what are called injection wells, or sometimes disposal wells. It is important to note that it is not the fracking process itself that usually causes these earthquakes; it is the rapid injection of fluid during wastewater disposal that sometimes pumps hundreds of millions of gallons of brine deep into the earth each year. As the wastewater is pumped underground, it gradually fills up crevices in the rock previously occupied by oil, until more and more pressure is needed to send the water down into the well. As pressure increases, it can trigger near-by faults, like the Wilzetta, to jump.
gpt3_answer: Oil and gas rigs can cause earthquakes and falls due to the drilling process. During the extraction process, high-pressure fluids are injected into the ground to fracture the rocks and release oil and gas. This process is known as hydraulic fracturing, or “fracking.” These fluids can create fractures in rocks that were previously stable, which can lead to seismic activity. Additionally, the drilling of oil and gas wells is done under tremendous weight and pressure, which can cause the earth to shift, resulting in earthquakes. Finally, these rigs are often placed on uneven ground, which can cause them to fall off balance and collapse, leading to potential injuries and fatalities.
alpaca_answer: Oil and gas rigs can cause earthquakes and falls due to a variety of factors. In some instances, the oil and gas operations can cause an increase in the pressure of the rocks and fluids below the surface, leading to a natural increase in seismic activity. In addition, if the oil and gas rigs are not properly installed, they can cause the ground above to sink, resulting in a fall in the surrounding area. Furthermore, if the oil and gas rigs are not properly maintained, they may cause a structure to weaken and collapse.</s>
gpt3_wdoc_answer: Oil and gas rigs may cause earthquakes and falls due to rapid injection of fluid during wastewater disposal. This process can pump hundreds of millions of gallons of brine deep into the earth each year and fill up crevices in the rock previously occupied by oil, creating an overpressure on the fault. This can reduce the stress that's pinning the fault into place, causing the fault to jump and trigger earthquakes. Falls can also occur due to the pressure of the injected fluids destabilizing the ground near the rigs, leading to a shift in the surface. To reduce the risk of these potential man-made quakes, companies and states can monitor operations more closely, impose tighter standards, and recycle wastewater from drilling instead of injecting it underground.

In addition, the disposal of wastewater into the earth can also cause falls if it occurs near an underground water source. The increased pressure from the injected water can cause the water table to rise and cause a fall in the nearby surface.</s>

In order to reduce the risk of an earthquake or fall, oil and gas companies must take steps to reduce the amount of pressure applied to the ground by the rig. This includes using softer drilling bits, drilling at a slower pace, and taking other measures to reduce the level of stress applied to the ground. Additionally, proper maintenance and inspection of the rig can help to ensure that it is in good condition and not at risk of a fall. By taking these steps, oil and gas companies can help to reduce the risk of earthquakes and falls due to their rigs.

question: How are you innocent before proven guilty, if you still have to spend time in jail until your trial?
human_answer: Search why are people jailed before going to court
webgpt_answer: Innocent until proven guilty is more of a legal principle than a reality, especially for those who can't afford to pay for their bail. When defendants are stuck in jail while awaiting trial, data indicate they're more likely to plead guilty or be found guilty of crimes. They're also likely to be given longer prison sentences. This is partly a result of their not being in a position to bargain with prosecutors, because they're stuck behind bars and desperate to move things along. For low-level crimes, all that time spent in pretrial detention can be equivalent to the length of the sentence they'll get if they're found guilty anyway. A poor defendant who can't afford bail may spend days, even weeks, in jail waiting to see a judge for a crime where prison time might not even be required. At that point, it's hard to justify spending time or money fighting the charge, even if backing down leaves an innocent person with a criminal record.
gpt3_answer: It is a fundamental right in the United States that a person is considered innocent until proven guilty. This is a core principle of our criminal justice system and is a cornerstone of the Constitution. Despite this, it is true that many people who are arrested and awaiting trial may have to spend time in jail until their trial is completed. This is because the court system can be very slow in setting trial dates and in some cases, it can take months or even years for a case to be heard.   In order to ensure that a person who is innocent until proven guilty is not subjected to undue hardship while awaiting trial, the courts have established bail rules. Bail is an amount of money that is set by the court in order to guarantee a person’s appearance in court. If the person posts the required amount of bail, they can be released from jail and allowed to remain free until their trial. In order to guarantee the person’s appearance in court, the court may require the person to surrender their passport, post a bond, or place the person under house arrest.   Furthermore, the court may impose certain conditions on a person’s release such as notifying the court of any address changes, abiding by a curfew, and not leaving the state or country. It is important to note that these conditions are set to ensure that the person appears in court and is not intended to be overly restrictive. In cases where a person is unable to post bail, the court may consider alternative forms of release such as supervised release or pretrial services.   Ultimately, the criminal justice system recognizes the importance of respecting a person’s right to remain innocent until proven guilty. By taking the appropriate steps, a person can ensure that they are not subjected to undue hardship while awaiting trial.

question: Why do VGA/DVI cables have to be screwed in, but HDMI and other cables don't?
human_answer: Video cables like DVI and VGA still use screw connectors mainly due to durability. A power cable like HDMI carries a stronger current than a video cable, so power cables are made thicker to contain the conductors. Thicker cables and the use of metal conductors make the cable more durable and resilient than a video cable. Video cables are made with more delicate pins and thinner wires, so they are easier to damage or accidentally disconnect. Screws prevent accidental disconnections or bends that might break the pins. HDMI cables are also good as temporary connectors, so a lack of screws makes them easier to plug in and disconnect quickly.
webgpt_answer: VGA and DVI cables have to be screwed in because monitor manufacturers require it. These cables were designed for slower, less frequent insertion and removal, and because of that, they lack the physical holding pressure of a USB connector, for example. HDMI cables don't require screws because it would cause several problems, including with the format of the screw and the screw hole diameter. Additionally, equipment manufacturers reserve the screw position, screw thread diameter, and other issues, which increases the cost of communication with the manufacturer and is not suitable for the trend of precision equipment in the new era. At the beginning of the design, designers wanted to support hot plugging of HDMI cables, so they were designed to be interchangeable.
gpt3_answer: VGA/DVI cables need to be screwed in to ensure a tight connection between the cable and the port. This helps to prevent any disruption or interference within the signal, as a loose connection can cause signal degradation or even complete loss of connection. HDMI and other cables, like USB or DisplayPort, use a different type of connector that doesn’t require screws. This connector typically has a locking mechanism that fits tightly into the port and holds the cable in place without the need for screws. The locking mechanism also helps to ensure a tight connection, and it’s more user-friendly because it’s much easier to plug in and unplug the cable.

This is because the connection is analog, and the signal has to be constantly kept in place to ensure a good picture. On the other hand, HDMI and other cables don’t have to be screwed in, because these are digital signals, which are able to transmit data even if slightly loose or at an angle.</s>

Additionally, the screws also help to protect against the cable being accidentally tugged and causing the monitor to crash to the floor.   On the other hand, HDMI and other cables don't have to be screwed in. This is because the design allows for hot-plugging, which makes it easier for users to quickly plug in and out. Furthermore, there are also practical reasons why HDMI cables don't come with screws, such as the difficulty in finding the right screw and thread size, as well as the increased cost of communication with the manufacturer.

question: Why do we use air filled tires and not tires made of solid rubber, that don't run the risk of going flat?
human_answer: Passenger vehicles use air filled tires because air acts as a medium for contraction and expansion to the tire. Air contracts and expands easily, therefore reducing wear and tear caused by the friction of rubber and the rims. The air in the tires also absorbs impact of a hole or bump due to its high suspension abilities. Tires made of solid rubber do not absorb vibrations because the solid construction of the tires makes them have no medium to absorb shocks, resulting in a rougher ride. Tires made of rubber weigh more than air-filled tires, which increases the engine load to run the vehicle. The car will accelerate slowly and waste fuel.
webgpt_answer: Air filled tires are used because they offer many benefits over solid rubber tires. For example, air can be compressed and adjust its volume easily, whereas a solid material like rubber would absorb and pass along the shock of striking an obstacle, making for a bumpy and uncomfortable ride. Additionally, air-filled tires have a lower rolling resistance, which means they minimize wasted energy as a tire rolls, which in turn decreases the required rolling effort. At high speeds, the amount of energy loss while passing over bumpy roads would be extremely inefficient for the car, and would cause tires to wear down much more quickly. Furthermore, solid rubber tires would face the same problems of tread loss at a faster rate, and due to the solid composition of the tires, would cost more to produce and dispose of, while also adding weight to the car as a whole, requiring more fuel expenditure.
gpt3_answer: Using air filled tires instead of tires made of solid rubber has several advantages. First, air filled tires provide better cushioning, allowing for a smoother ride. This reduces the amount of vibration and shock that would otherwise be experienced when driving, which helps to protect the car, its passengers, and other vehicles on the road. Furthermore, air filled tires offer better traction and provide better handling. The flexibility of the air filled tires allows them to adjust to the road surface, thereby improving grip and cornering performance.   Another major benefit of using air filled tires is that they are much lighter than solid rubber tires. This is important not only because it increases fuel efficiency, but also because it reduces the overall weight of the vehicle, meaning that it accelerates faster, takes less time to stop, and is more maneuverable.   Finally, air filled tires are much less prone to going flat. This is because the air provides an extra layer of protection, making it harder for sharp objects to puncture the tire wall. Even if a tire does go flat, it is much easier and less expensive to replace than a solid rubber tire.

Solid rubber tires do not have the same cushioning effect, which can lead to a less comfortable ride. Additionally, air filled tires provide better grip on the road, which can help improve the overall performance of the vehicle. 
 
 Furthermore, air filled tires are also easier to repair than solid rubber tires. Should there be a problem with a tire, it can easily be repaired by patching up the small hole or puncture. Solid rubber tires are much harder to repair, requiring complete replacement if there is a problem. 
 
 Overall, air filled tires are preferred over solid rubber tires due to the better ride and handling they provide, as well as the ease of repair.</s>

question: How do animals sense the upcoming earthquake?
human_answer: Animals can sense an earthquake seconds before humans because many animals sense a primary wave, or "P wave," before the larger, secondary wave that humans feel. Some animals are believed to be able to detect earthquakes hours or days before an earthquake hits. We do not know for certain if this is plausible because it is nearly impossible to do a controlled study on animal behavior prior to an earthquake, but there have been many reports of animals fleeing prior to the onset of an earthquake. One theory for why animals may be able to detect earthquakes so early on is that they are more sensitive to the Earth's vibrations than humans are. Another theory is that they can sense electrical changes in the air. Because some animals, like elephants, pass knowledge on from generation, it may also be possible that some older animals who have experienced an earthquake teach their young how to react to certain geographical signs.
webgpt_answer: There are various theories as to how animals sense earthquakes before humans, ranging from the detection of electrical changes in the air to gas released from the Earth. One theory is that animals feel the Earth vibrate before humans do. Another is that certain animals sense the earthquake itself, even if it's thousands of miles away. One review of studies found that elephants and whales can hear infrasound, and that the infrasonic waves generated during the earthquake may aid them in detecting the earthquake. However, the authors of the review also found that the supposed "predictive" behavior in animals occurred around the same time as "foreshocks"—smaller earthquakes that precede the main seismic event. If this is the case, then what people interpret as animals' ability to "predict" earthquakes may in fact be reactions to the vibrations or sounds from earthquakes that are too faint for us humans to detect.
gpt3_answer: Animals can sense the upcoming earthquake in several ways. Studies have found that animals can detect the vibrations of the earth before humans can, as well as changes in the atmosphere and the magnetic field of the earth. Animals can pick up on subtle shifts in the air pressure and electromagnetic waves that happen before an earthquake. Additionally, animals have an incredibly keen sense of smell and hearing, and can pick up on the scent of gases that are released from the ground before an earthquake. Some animals can even detect seismic activity through the ground with their feet. These pre-seismic signals are usually very subtle and hard for humans to detect, but animals can pick up on them and react accordingly. This is why animals are often seen fleeing an area before an earthquake strikes.
alpaca_answer: Animals have developed different ways of sensing seismic activity in the upcoming earthquake. Others, such as rodents and some birds, are able to sense changes in the atmospheric pressure that come along with an approaching earthquake. Additionally, some animals may have a heightened sense of alertness and anxiety that can make them more aware of the environment in the moments before an earthquake strikes. Finally, some animals may have evolved to flee the area prior to an earthquake, though this is much less common. Overall, animals have a variety of different methods of sensing an upcoming earthquake and fleeing the area to safety.</s>

question: Were major news outlets established with political bias or was it formed over time?
human_answer: News media bias dates back almost as far as news media itself, whereas media objectivity is a relatively recent concept. Historically, newspapers and other forms of news media were created with a clear connection to a political party and an economic motive. They were made to push opinions, garner attention with sensationalist content, influence voters toward a specific agenda, and make a profit for the publisher. Bias is almost impossible to avoid when covering the news. Whether deliberate or not, bias can appear in word choice, release times, media sponsors, tone of voice, and included perspectives. The number of perspectives on an issue also poses a problem for objective journalism, since each issue has so many sides that no one story can cover them all, and any omitted positions can lead to accusations of bias. Most news outlets were formed with the same intentions, to represent certain sides or all sides of an issue and to make a profit off readers. Each developed strategies to curb bias that may have led to leaning toward one political side or another; however, some are more intentional in expressing biased opinions than others.
webgpt_answer: It is important to understand that media bias did not start with the modern news outlets we have today. In fact, it has been a part of the news industry since the beginning. Around the 1830s, most newspapers were aligned with a political party or platform and would often publish anonymous political figures as part of their sponsored content. It was not until the commercialization of the newspaper industry that most outlets began to distance themselves from political parties in order to appeal to a wider audience and increase profits. When the cost of publishing a daily paper in the largest cities grew too high, party subsidies no longer covered operating costs, and new revenue sources like department stores and other retailers began to pressure editors to expand their reach and be less partisan. Consequently, most newspapers and broadcast networks tried to present the news objectively by the 1950s.

question: Why do I sweat more after getting out of the shower?
human_answer: Sweating's main role is to maintain a normal temperature especially when the body temperature or the surrounding temperature begins to rise. With this in mind, taking a warm or hot shower, which raises the body temperature, can lead to excessive sweating. Similarly, humidity in the bathroom triggers sweating as the body tries to lower the body temperature, which is elevated due to the surrounding environment. Rubbing the body vigorously with a towel can generate heat and cause the body to sweat in order to maintain its temperature. Finally, wearing warm clothes after showering can cause sweating.

The steam that a hot shower produces proves this. Hot water that remains on the skin and hair continues to warm the body after a shower. The vapor from hot water, combined with the warmer temperature, raises the humidity and temperature of the bathroom, which thereby raises body temperature and makes one sweat. If the sweating seems to get worse once you start toweling off, the very act of drying your skin may be contributing to the problem. Rubbing the skin with a towel creates friction, which also creates heat. Also, if the clothing and towel used after a shower are warm, they can immediately warm the body and lead to sweating.

It's also important to make sure to dry off completely, as even a small amount of moisture can cause your body to sweat. Additionally, wearing loose, breathable clothing will help to keep your body temperature down. Finally, avoiding hot showers and making sure to take cooler showers can help to reduce sweating after your shower.

question: I made a video explaining the Monty Hall Problem, I thought you guys might be interested!
human_answer: The Monty Hall problem is based on understanding odds of a game.  There are three doors in the game.  Two doors are losing choices and one is the winning prize.  The game player chooses one door to find the winning prize.  The game host then removes one of the losing doors.  The game player then gets the choice to change their pick or remain with the original choice.  If the game player remains with their original choice they have a 1/3 chance in winning.  If the game player alters their pick to the other door they have a 2/3 chance in winning.  This is because the game host always removes a door which is a losing choice, thus increasing the odds for the game player from 1/3 to 2/3.

After the contestant chooses a door, the host reveals one of the two goats behind the other doors, leaving the contestant with two choices: stick with their original choice or switch to the other remaining door. The odds of winning by switching are two-thirds of the time, while the odds of winning by sticking are one-third of the time. This is because there is a greater probability that the contestant originally picked a door with a goat, meaning that the other door the host revealed is the other door with a goat, resulting in a 2/3 chance of winning by switching.

When the contestant opens one of the two unopened doors, the host, Monty, opens the other unopened door to reveal a goat. The contestant then has the option to switch to the other remaining door. In the long run, should the contestant stick with the door they chose or switch to the other remaining door?

The answer to this seemingly simple problem lies in the probability of not finding the goat if you switch. The chance of finding the goat behind the other unopened door is only 1/3 or 33.3%, so if you switch, you have a 33.3% chance of winning no matter what door you choose. However, if you stay, the chances of you being right are reduced to 1/2 or 50%.

In sum, sticking with the door you chose gives you a 1/3 chance of winning, while switching to the other door gives you a 1/3 chance of winning. Since 1/3 and 1/3 are the same, you are better off switching to the other door to increase your chances of winning. This is regardless of whether you open the other door or not. Therefore, in the long run, it is better to switch to the other door.</s>

question: How did the newscaster cadence come to be?
human_answer: Newscasters speak in General American which is a type of english in which there accents are dropped in favor of fully pronounced words.  For example, a Texas born reporter will drop their accent in order to find work outside of their local market.  In addition, many broadcasters may be emulating their idols which causes speech patterns to be passed down.  Furthermore, the microphones used to record the newscasters voice are sensitive to particular words which need to be carefully pronounced.  There are also broadcaster training programs which teach people to speak without regional accents and to use standard broadcast English.

They also tend to enunciate more precisely than the average person, and some may even use a certain sing-song inflection on less important words in order to avoid monotony. One reason why newscasters share speech patterns is that they are all taught to use standard broadcasting English, a form of pronunciation in which no letters are dropped. For example, they must always say "fishing," not "fishin'." They also speak more slowly than people do in daily life in order to be easily understandable. Moreover, most broadcasters tend to emulate the voices of their role models, and so speech patterns get passed down.

question: What is the difference between LED, LCD, Plasma and LED LCD TVs?
human_answer: Plasma TVs are full of tiny compartments of gas. When a voltage reaches the gas, the gas is excited into a plasma state containing mercury, and the voltage triggers the mercury to emit UV rays. The rays pass through red, green, and blue phosphor cells in each pixel on the screen, creating a color image with the light produced by the pixels. LCD TV pixels do not produce their own light like plasma TV pixels, so they use a backlight instead. When the backlight is turned on, it sends a voltage to the pixels that rotates them, turning them to either let the backlight's light through and make an image or block the light to show black. Older LCD TVs used Cold-Cathode Fluorescent Lamps (CCFLs) as a backlight, but newer ones use light-emitting diodes (LEDs) instead and are called LED LCDs. LED TVs are the same as LED LCDs since they function the same way LCD TVs do, but they use LED lights around the edges of the screen or covering the back panel rather than CCFLs.

LED and LCD are the same technology. The difference between the two is the backlighting technique used. They also produce better contrast and have a brighter image. LED TVs also produce a sharp, detailed and bright visual image. And are a good choice for use in a very bright room.

Plasma HDTVs create images using phosphors, tiny plasma containers placed between two sheets of glass. These emit ultraviolet light at colored spots of phosphor on the screen, which then glow to create the picture.

According to CNET, LED-lit LCD TVs are the brightest available. They are capable of 100 footlamberts, although this is bright enough to cause eye fatigue in a dark room. Plasmas are less bright, so they might be more difficult to see in a bright room, and will dim over time.

LCD TVs use liquid crystal display (LCD) technology to create the image on the screen. LCD TVs use liquid crystals that are activated using a backlight to create the image. LCD TVs are thinner and lighter than older CRT TVs, but they generally lack the picture quality and contrast of LED TVs.   Plasma TVs use a gas-filled plasma display to create the image on the screen. Plasma TVs generally have brighter displays and better contrast than LCD TVs.   LED LCD TVs are a combination of LED and LCD technology. They use LEDs to create the backlight for the LCD display. This allows for a thinner and lighter TV that has a brighter display and better contrast than traditional LCD TVs. LED LCD TVs are generally less expensive than LED TVs, but they are still more expensive than LCD TVs.

question: the flow of electrons during the production of electricity
human_answer: Electricity happens when electrons move from one atom to another An atom is the smallest constituent unit of an element that can exist, but within each atom, there are three particles: electrons, protons, and neutrons. The electrons carry a negative electromagnetic charge and have unique characteristics that allow them to skip from one atom to another. This movement of electrons from one atom to another is what creates an electric current.

This movement of electrons from one atom to another is what creates an electric current. A consistent flow of electrons within a circuit determines the current in a wire.

This flow of electrons is called an electric current and it is what produces the electricity.  The electrons flow through the conductor in a random direction and with a random speed. This flow of electrons is affected by the resistance of the conductor, the voltage of the source, and the temperature of the conductor. As electrons flow through the conductor, they transfer their energy to the wire and cause it to heat up. This heat is then dissipated through the air or through a cooling system.  The flow of electrons is also affected by induction, where an electric current is induced in a conductor by a changing magnetic field. This process is used in electric motors and generators to produce electricity.  The flow of electrons is ultimately what causes electricity to be produced. question: How does evolution occur and how did the first living organisms come about
human_answer:
An experiment in 1952 revealed that a gaseous mixture of boiling water, hydrogen gas, ammonia, and methane - four chemicals that were likely present on the early Earth - subjected to repeated electric shocks, similar to the lightning strikes that would been historically common on Earth, could give rise to amino acids. Amino acids are often described as the building blocks of life, since they form the proteins that control most biochemical processes in our bodies. 
Cyanobacteria evolved at least 2.4 billion years ago. They became Earth's first photo-synthesizers, making food using water and the Sun’s energy, and releasing oxygen as a result. This catalyzed a sudden surge in oxygen that made the environment less hospitable for other microbes - single cells with no organelles and no nuclei to package their DNA - that could not tolerate oxygen.
Eventually, microbes began to live inside other microbes, functioning as organelles for them. Mitochondria, the organelles that process food into energy, evolved from these mutually beneficial relationships, and DNA became packaged in nuclei. The new complex cells, or eukaryotic cells, had specialized parts playing specialized roles that supported the whole cell. Cells also began living together, probably because it was more beneficial. For example, groups of cells might be able to feed more efficiently or gain protection from simply being bigger. Cells began to support the needs of the group by each cell doing a specific job, such as holding the group together or making digestive enzymes. These clusters of specialized, cooperating cells eventually became the first animals, which DNA evidence suggests evolved around 800 million years ago.
webgpt_answer: The process of abiogenesis, or the emergence of life from non-living matter, is still not fully understood and is the subject of much debate among scientists.  Several theories exist, one of the most well-known being the "primordial soup" theory, which proposes that in the early stages of Earth's history, organic matter was exposed to energy in the form of volcanoes and electrical storms, which would have catalyzed chemical reactions that could have produced self-replicating molecules.  Evidence of this theory is supported by the fact that organic compounds can be produced from inorganic "precursors" in the lab.  Another theory is that a single ancient gene may have used each of its opposite DNA strands to code for different chemical catalysts, which would have both activated amino acids, which then formed proteins - essential to the production of living cells.  Additionally, it is believed that over the course of hundreds of millions of years, pre-biotic molecules evolved into self-replicating molecules by natural selection.
gpt3_answer: Evolution is the process in which species change over time through genetic mutations and natural selection. It is a slow and gradual process that can take thousands, millions, or even billions of years. As species evolve, they become better adapted to their environment, leading to the diversification of life on Earth.   The first living organisms on Earth are believed to have emerged around 3.5 billion years ago in the form of single-celled organisms. These primitive organisms are thought to have originated from a process known as abiogenesis, where life is created from non-living organic matter. This could have occurred through a combination of energy, heat, and organic compounds that were present on Earth at the time. However, the exact process of how life formed still remains a mystery.   Once these living organisms appeared, the process of evolution began. Genetic mutations gave rise to variations in traits and characteristics, which then led to natural selection. Natural selection is the process by which the most suitable traits and characteristics are passed down from one generation to the next, enabling species to survive and adapt to their environment. Over time, these changes accumulate and lead to the formation of new species.   In conclusion, evolution is the process by which species change over time through genetic mutations and natural selection. It is believed that the first living organisms on Earth emerged around 3.5 billion years ago, likely through a process called abiogenesis. Once these organisms appeared, the process of evolution began, culminating in the diversification of life we see today.

These molecules formed more complex molecules, which then organized into self-replicating molecules, and eventually into the first living organisms.</s>

This energy catalyzed chemical reactions that, in the span of a few hundred million years, could have produced self-replicating molecules. Over the span of a few hundred million years, natural selection pushed these single-celled organisms to evolve and adapt to the environment, eventually giving rise to the vast array of living organisms that exist today. question: How long is a second? How heavy is a gram? How far is a meter? Who came up with these definitions, and what lead to them being standardised?
human_answer:
Historically, the second was defined by the Earth's rotation cycle. However, it is now formally and more steadily defined in the International System of Units (SI) as being equal to the time duration of 9,192,631,770 periods of the radiation corresponding to the transition between the two hyperfine levels of the fundamental unperturbed ground-state of the caesium-133 atom.
The meter originated in France in the 1790s as one/ten-millionth of the distance from the equator to the north pole along a meridian through Paris. Its definition has been updated several times throughout history, most recently in 1984 by the Geneva Conference on Weights and Measures. The meter is now defined as the distance light travels, in a vacuum, in 1/299,792,458 seconds with time measured by a cesium-133 atomic clock which emits pulses of radiation at very rapid, regular intervals.
The gram was originally defined as "the absolute weight of a volume of pure water equal to the cube of the hundredth part of a metre, and at the temperature of melting ice" (later at 4 °C, the temperature of maximum density of water). Currently, a gram is defined as one thousandth of the SI base unit, the kilogram, or 1×10−3 kg, which itself is defined by the International Bureau of Weights and Measures, not in terms of grams, but by taking the fixed numerical value of the Planck constant h to be 6.626 070 15×10−34 kg⋅m^2⋅s−1.
webgpt_answer: The definitions for many common measurements were derived from the old definition of a second, which was based on the rotation of the Earth. A day was arbitrarily divided into 24 hours, the hour into 60 minutes, and the minute into 60 seconds. However, the Earth doesn't rotate uniformly, and its rotation decreases at a rate of about 20 millionths of a second every calendar year due to tidal friction caused by the Moon. The first clock with a hand indicating seconds was built between 1560-70, and in 1579, we had the first clock with second markings. However, they weren't very accurate, and the second remained arbitrary from machine to machine and unable to be reliably measured. In 1670, William Clement tinkered with the physics and built a clock precise enough that the second was now an established unit of time. By 1862 it was established that the second would be the base unit of time for all scientific research, along with the millimeter and milligram. The meter is the base unit in the International System of Units and is equal to the distance travelled by light through a vacuum in 1/299,792,458 seconds.

question: Why do dogs shake their legs when you scratch a certain part of them?
human_answer: Dogs shake or kick their legs when you scratch them because of a completely involuntary reaction known as the scratch reflex. When you scratch or tickle your dog's belly, it irritates him, much the same way that the wind or a bug might. This activates nerves under his skin that are connected to his spinal cord and relays a message to his leg muscles to kick in an attempt to get rid of the irritant. The scratch reflex may have an adaptive purpose of ridding the animal from fleas or other dangerous parasites in an area (the flanks) that isn't as highly mobile as say, the tail or the dog's front or hind legs. The scratch reflex therefore may allow the dog to quickly attempt to remove the stimulus by using his rear leg.
webgpt_answer: The scratching exhibited by dogs while being petted is a reflex called the scratch reflex. The scratched area that elicits the response can vary from dog to dog, but the belly, chest and sides are the most likely locations to activate it. The reflex may occur because scratching makes the dog feel like she has an itch, or it may be a lingering defensive reflex and not the result of any particular physical sensation. human_answer: "Gleeking" is the term for the projection of saliva from your mouth, caused by compression of the tongue on the submandibular gland. If the mouth is open, the jet of saliva may project several feet.  Spontaneous gleeking may occur due to accidental tongue pressure on the sublingual gland while talking, eating, yawning, or cleaning the teeth.

question: after World War II, what changes did Germany make to it's own political system to ensure a dictator figure could never take power again?
human_answer: After World War II, Germany at first had little say in its political system. It was divided into zones governed by the Allied countries and France, and it separated into a democratic West Germany and a socialist East Germany. Years later, as the division between the two was breaking down, the East German government rewrote their constitution and held free elections rather than appointing a head of state. During the reunification that joined West and East Germany, the Chancellor also mandated that the united country had to join NATO, further pressing their status as a democracy rather than a controlled communist government. The union of East and West Germany absorbed the East into the West, resulting in a constitution based on West Germany's with settlements and amendments that were voted into law and eliminated controlling measures that could lead to a dictatorship rather than a democracy.

They did this by writing a constitution that protects the freedom of individuals, guarantees their dignity, and ensures that all people are treated equally before the law.  This constitution also subjects state power to strict controls through the separation of powers.  This is to prevent a dictator from ever seizing power in Germany again.  Germany also makes sure that only parties that overcome the constitutional 5-percent threshold in an election are allowed to take seats in the Bundestag.  This rule is intended to give the Bundestag stability.  Another institution that keeps an eye on power sharing, fundamental rights, and democracy is the Federal Constitutional Court.  Its main duty is the judicial review - examining laws for their constitutionality, and thus helping all citizens to enforce their rights and freedoms against the state.

The Basic Law also limited the power of the executive, ensuring that decisions were subject to review by the legislature. question: Many see in the flag of the Confederate States of America a symbol of racism. But why does noone see it as symbol of (high) treason against the United States of America (aka "The Union")?
human_answer: Some people do view the Confederate flag as a treasonous symbol, but the flag has taken on multiple meanings since the end of the Civil War. Following the war, many African-Americans and northeners interpreted the flag as a symbol of disunity. White southerners began to view the flag as a memorial, and since then, that sentiment has transformed for many people not as a symbol of their position in the war but as a regional symbol. However, because of the history of slavery and violence tied specifically to the southern United States, many people also interpret the display of a Confederate flag as a symbol of this violence.
webgpt_answer: The Confederate flag was indeed a symbol of treason against the United States of America. The Confederate States of America was a breakaway nation that issued its own currency, elected its own president and congress, and raised an army to go to war with the United States of America. The war that the Confederacy waged against the United States was one of the bloodiest in American history, resulting in more than 110,000 U.S. soldiers killed. Some will take issue with calling the Confederacy traitors, but that is exactly what they were. The flag was flown by the Confederate army during the Civil War and was later used by the Ku Klux Klan and others to resist desegregation in the 1950s. Today, the Confederate flag is flown by some as a symbol of Southern pride and heritage, while others see it as a symbol of racism and white supremacy.

The CSA was formed out of a very real fear of a loss of rights and autonomy, and many saw the Union’s actions as a violation of their state’s rights. While this does not excuse the Confederate’s actions, it does explain why treason is not necessarily the first thing people think of when they see the Confederate flag. question: Is there a speed of heat transferral?
human_answer: Yes; the speed of heat transferral is proportional to the difference in temperature between two locations. If there is a large temperature difference between two areas, heat will transfer quickly. If there is no difference in temperature, heat will not transfer at all.
webgpt_answer: There is a speed of heat transfer, but it is not a single number. The speed of heat transfer depends on several factors, including the area through which the heat is being conducted, the distance the heat must be conducted, and the substance that the heat is being conducted through. For example, heat transfer through windows of homes is dependent upon the size of the window. More heat will be lost from a home through a larger window than through a smaller window of the same composition and thickness. Similarly, heat escape through a Styrofoam cup will escape more rapidly through a thin-walled cup than through a thick-walled cup. The rate of heat transfer is inversely proportional to the thickness of the cup. A similar statement can be made for heat being conducted through a layer of cellulose insulation in the wall of a home. The thicker that the insulation is, the lower the rate of heat transfer.
gpt3_answer: Yes, there is a speed at which heat can be transferred. Heat transfer occurs in three different ways: conduction, convection, and radiation. Radiation is the transfer of heat through electromagnetic waves, such as when you put a pot of boiling water in the microwave.   The speed of heat transfer depends on the type of heat transfer. In conduction, heat transfer is dependent on the thermal conductivity of the material, which is the ability of a material to conduct heat. For instance, a material with a high thermal conductivity, such as copper, will conduct heat more quickly than a material with a low thermal conductivity, such as wood. In convection, the speed of heat transfer is dependent on the speed of the fluid that is moving, as well as the temperature difference between the two fluids. In radiation, the speed of heat transfer is dependent on the wavelength of the radiation and the temperature difference between the two objects.   In all cases, heat transfer occurs at different speeds depending on the type of heat transfer and the materials or fluids involved. However, the speed of heat transfer is typically measured in watts per meter per Kelvin (W/mK). This is the rate of energy transfer in watts per meter of material per degree Kelvin of temperature difference.
